Name: Requiring the Mayor’s Office of Operations to report data regarding utilization of and applications for citywide temporary emergency housing and associated services.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the Mayor’s Office of Operations to report data regarding utilization of and applications for citywide temporary emergency housing and associated services.

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on General Welfare
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Amendment Proposed by Comm
This Introduction was Amended by Committee
A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Committee approved by Roll Call.
A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Council approved by Consent Roll Call.
This Introduction was Sent to Mayor by Council
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Mayor
This Introduction was Signed Into Law by Mayor
This Introduction was Recved from Mayor by Council

\v0\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj\ul Be it enacted by the Council as follows: \par
\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj\ulnone Section 1. Findings and Intent. Many city agencies administer facilities that provide services, including temporary places to stay, for families and individuals who do not have anywhere to stay overnight or who need assistance finding or maintaining stable housing.  While the Department of Homeless Services (\ldblquote DHS\rdblquote ) administers the majority of these facilities and DHS regularly reports on the utilization of the services in its purview, it does not report on those administered by other city agencies, such as the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the Human Resources Administration and the Department of Youth and Community Development.  Not having regular data concerning the number of people who utilize such facilities and who are being served by agencies other than DHS can result in the significant undercounting of the number of people in New York City who need temporary emergency housing and those who utilize associated services.  In order to accurately determine the extent of the need for temporary emergency housing and associated services in the city, the Council finds that all agencies that provide such housing and services must routinely report the number of individuals and/or families who utilize such facilities.  \par
\'a7 2. Chapter 1 of title 3 of the administrative code of the city of New York is amended by adding a new section 3-113 to read as follows: \par
\ul\'a73-113. a. Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following terms shall have the following meanings:  \par
(1)  \ldblquote Adult\rdblquote  shall mean an individual 18 years of age or older;\par
(2)  \ldblquote Adult families\rdblquote  shall mean families comprised of adults and no children under the age of 18;\par
(3)  \ldblquote Children\rdblquote  shall mean individuals under the age of 18;\par
(4) \ldblquote City-administered facilities\rdblquote  shall mean hotels, shelters and other accommodations or associated services, managed by or provided under contract or similar agreement with any city agency, provided to individuals or families who need temporary emergency housing or assistance finding or maintaining stable housing;\par
(5)  \ldblquote DHS\rdblquote  shall mean the department of homeless services;\par
(6) \ldblquote DHS-administered facilities\rdblquote  shall mean city-administered facilities managed directly by DHS or by a provider under contract or similar agreement with DHS;\par
(7)  \ldblquote DHS drop-in centers\rdblquote  shall mean city-administered facilities that provide single adults with hot meals, showers, laundry facilities, clothing, medical care, recreational space, employment referrals and/or housing placement services, but not overnight housing;   \par
(8)  \ldblquote DHS faith-based beds\rdblquote  shall mean city-administered facilities that provide overnight housing to individuals, are affiliated with one or more religious groups and receive client referrals through organizations under contract with DHS;\par
(9)  \ldblquote DHS safe havens\rdblquote  shall mean city-administered facilities that provide low-threshold, harm-reduction housing to chronic street homeless individuals, who are referred to such facilities through a DHS outreach program, without the obligation of entering into other supportive and rehabilitative services in order to reduce barriers to temporary housing;\par
(10)  \ldblquote DHS stabilization beds\rdblquote  shall mean city-administered facilities that provide a short-term housing option for a chronic street homeless individual while such individual works with his/her outreach team to locate a more permanent housing option;\par
(11)  \ldblquote DHS veterans shelters\rdblquote  shall mean city-administered facilities that provide short-term housing for people who actively served in the United States military;\par
(12)  \ldblquote DYCD\rdblquote  shall mean the department of youth and community development;\par
(13)  \ldblquote DYCD-administered crisis shelters\rdblquote  shall mean city-administered facilities that provide short-term emergency housing for runaway and homeless youth and are managed by a provider under contract or similar agreement with DYCD;\par
(14)  \ldblquote DYCD-administered drop-in centers\rdblquote  shall mean city-administered facilities that provide runaway and homeless youth and their families with services, counseling and referrals from trained youth workers;\par
(15)  \ldblquote DYCD-administered facilities\rdblquote  shall mean city-administered facilities managed by a provider under contract or similar agreement with DYCD;\par
(16)  \ldblquote DYCD-administered transitional independent living facilities\rdblquote  shall mean city-administered facilities that provide long-term residential services to runaway and homeless youth for up to 18 months and are managed by a provider under contract or similar agreement with DYCD;\par
(17)  \ldblquote Families with children\rdblquote  shall mean families with children under the age of 18, couples including at least one pregnant woman, single pregnant women, or parents or grandparents with a pregnant individual; \par
(18)  \ldblquote HPD\rdblquote  shall mean the department of housing preservation and development;\par
(19)  \ldblquote HPD-administered facilities\rdblquote  shall mean city-administered facilities managed by a provider under contract or similar agreement with HPD;\par
(20)  \ldblquote HPD emergency facilities\rdblquote  shall mean shelters providing emergency shelter managed by a provider under contract or similar agreement with HPD;\par
(21) \ldblquote HPD emergency hotels\rdblquote  shall mean hotels providing emergency shelter to individuals or families displaced from their homes managed by a provider under contract or similar agreement with HPD;\par
(22)  \ldblquote HRA\rdblquote  shall mean the human resources administration;\par
(23)  \ldblquote HRA-administered facilities\rdblquote  shall mean city-administered facilities managed directly by HRA or by a provider under contract or similar agreement with HRA, excluding non-emergency supportive housing;\par
(24)  \ldblquote HRA domestic violence shelters\rdblquote  shall mean shelters for victims of domestic violence managed directly by HRA or by a provider under contract or similar agreement with HRA;\par
(25)  \ldblquote HRA HASA emergency housing\rdblquote  shall mean single room occupancy hotels managed by a provider under contract or similar agreement with HRA to provide emergency shelter for recipients of services from the HIV/AIDS Services Administration;\par
(26)  \ldblquote HRA HASA transitional housing\rdblquote  shall mean congregate facilities managed by a provider under contract or similar agreement with HRA to provide emergency shelter for recipients of services from the HIV/AIDS Services Administration; and; and\par
(27)   \ldblquote Unduplicated\rdblquote  shall mean counted only once within the reporting period.\par
b. Reports of citywide utilization data.  The mayor\rquote s office of operations shall create a portal on the NYCStat page of the city\rquote s website, or any successor pages of such website that are substantially similar in form and function, in order to publish citywide data regarding the utilization of city-administered facilities.  Commencing on November 1, 2011, and no later than the first day of each month thereafter, the mayor\rquote s office of operations shall for each month, calendar year and fiscal year publish via such portal the: \par
(1) average daily overnight census for each of the following categories: \par
A.  DHS drop-in centers, disaggregated by single men, single women and total single adults; and\par
B.  DHS faith-based facilities, disaggregated by single men, single women and total single adults.\par
(2) average daily overnight census; and (3) number of unduplicated persons or families utilizing city-administered facilities for each of the following categories: \par
C. all DHS-administered facilities, disaggregated by families with children, adult families, total families, total adults in families, total children, single men, single women and total single adults;\par
D.  DHS safe havens, disaggregated by single men, single women and total single adults;\par
E.  DHS stabilization beds, disaggregated by single men, single women and total single adults;\par
F.  DHS veterans shelters, disaggregated by single men, single women and total single adults;\par
G.  HPD-administered facilities, disaggregated by families with children, adult families, total families, total adults in families, total children, single men, single women and total single adults;\par
H.  HPD emergency facilities, disaggregated by families with children, adult families, total families, total adults in families, total children, single men, single women and total single adults;\par
I. HPD emergency hotels, disaggregated by families with children, adult families, total families, total adults in families, total children, single men, single women and total single adults;\par
J.  HRA-administered facilities, disaggregated by families with children, adult families, total families, total adults in families, total children, single men, single women and total single adults;\par
K. HRA domestic violence shelters, disaggregated by families with children, adult families, total families, total adults in families, total children, single men, single women and total single adults;\par
L. HRA HASA emergency housing, disaggregated by families with children, adult families, total families, total adults in families, total children, single men, single women and total single adults;\par
M. HRA HASA transitional housing, disaggregated by families with children, adult families, total families, total adults in families, total children, single men, single women and total single adults; and\par
N. all city-administered facilities, excluding DYCD-administered facilities, disaggregated by families with children, adult families, total families, total adults in families, total children, single men, single women and total single adults.\par
(4)  average monthly utilization rates; and (5) number of unduplicated persons or families utilizing city-administered facilities for each of the following categories:\par
A.  DYCD-administered facilities, disaggregated by families with children, adult families, total families, total adults in families, total children, single men, single women and total single adults ;\par
B. DYCD-administered crisis shelters, disaggregated by families with children, adult families, total families, total adults in families, total children, single men, single women and total single adults;\par
C.  DYCD- administered drop-in centers, disaggregated by families with children, adult families, total families, total adults in families, total children, single men, single women and total single adults; and\par
D.  DYCD-administered transitional independent living facilities, disaggregated by families with children, adult families, total families, total adults in families, total children, single men, single women and total single adults.\par
(6)  the number of individuals who are on wait-lists for DYCD-administered facilities, to the extent such wait-lists exist, disaggregated by:  \par
A.  type of DYCD-administered facility; and\par
B. families with children, adult families, total families, single men, single women, and total single adults. \par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\sl480\slmult1\qj\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj (7)  the average length of stay disaggregated by:  \par
A. families with children, adult families, total families, single men, single women, and total single adults; \par
B. type of DHS-administered facility, excluding DHS drop-in centers and DHS faith-based beds; \par
C. type of DYCD-administered facility, excluding DYCD-administered drop-in centers; \par
D. type of HPD-administered facility; and\par
E. type of HRA-administered facility.\par
(8) the total number of facilities, disaggregated by DHS-administered facilities and facilities not administered by DHS.   \par
c.  Application and entrance data.  Commencing on November 1, 2011, and no later than the first day of each month thereafter, the mayor\rquote s office of operations shall for each month, calendar year and fiscal year publish in the same location on the NYCStat website as the data posted pursuant to subdivision b of this section, the following data for those seeking admission and entrance to DHS-administered facilities:  (1) the total number of:\par
A. applications;\par
B.  unduplicated applicants; \par
C.  applicants found eligible for shelter; \par
D.  entrants to DHS administered facilities; and\par
E.  unduplicated entrants to DHS-administered facilities.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\sl480\slmult1\qj The data required by subparagraphs A, B, C, D and E of this paragraph shall be disaggregated by families with children, adult families, total families, single men, single women, and total single adults;  \par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\sl480\slmult1\ulnone\tab (\ul 2)  the number of families with children found eligible for city-administered facilities;\par
\ulnone\tab\ul (3)  the percentage of eligible families with children who submitted one application;\par
\ulnone\tab\ul (4)  the percentage of eligible families with children who submitted two applications;\par
\ulnone\tab\ul (5)  the percentage of eligible families with children who submitted three applications;\par
\ulnone\tab\ul (6)  the percentage of eligible families with children who submitted four applications;\par
\ulnone\tab\ul (7)  the percentage of eligible families with children who submitted five applications;\par
\ulnone\tab\ul (8)  the percentage of eligible families with children who submitted six applications or more;\par
\ulnone\tab (\ul 9)  the number of adult families found eligible for city-administered facilities;\par
\ulnone\tab\ul (10)  the percentage of eligible adult families who submitted one application;\par
\ulnone\tab (\ul 11)  the percentage of eligible adult families who submitted two applications;\par
\ulnone\tab\ul (12)  the percentage of eligible adult families who submitted three applications;\par
\ulnone\tab\ul (13)  the percentage of eligible adult families who submitted four applications;\par
\ulnone\tab\ul (14) the percentage of eligible adult families who submitted five applications; and\par
\ulnone\tab\ul (15)  the percentage of eligible adult families who submitted six applications or more.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1 d.  The data required to be published in subdivisions b and c above shall be published electronically on the portal specified in subdivision b in a commonly available non-proprietary database format that is suitable for analysis.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\sl480\slmult1\ulnone\'a73. This local law shall take effect immediately.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj\par
